form-instructions.married: To estimate your benefits, we will need the following information from your {{year}} tax return and your partner's {{year}} tax return.
form-instructions.single: To estimate your benefits, we will need the following information from your {{year}} tax return:

info.claimed-income: Income claimed by you (line 11700 and line 12500 of your tax return). If field is left blank, we will assume it is zero.
info.claimed-repayment: Repayment claimed by you (line 21300 and line 23200 of your tax return). If field is left blank, we will assume it is zero.
info.net-income: Line 23600 on your tax return. If your net income is negative, enter '0'
info.partner-claimed-income: Income claimed by your spouse/partner (line 11700 and line 12500 of their tax return). If field is left blank, we will assume it is zero.
info.partner-claimed-repayment: Repayment claimed by your spouse/partner (line 21300 and line 23200 of their tax return). If field is left blank, we will assume it is zero.
info.partner-net-income: Line 23600 on your spouse/partners tax return. If your the net income is negative, enter '0'

items: Taxable scholarships, fellowships, bursaries and artists' project grants (line 13010)
Business income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 13500)
Professional income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 13700)
Commission income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 13900)
Farming income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 14100)
Fishing income (use 0 if the amount is negative) (line 14300)
working-income.text1: To determine your working income, add up all the following types of income:
working-income.text2: If your working income is negative, enter '0'.

index.about: The CDB Estimator is a tool to help users estimate their potential Canada Disability Benefit amount

content.completion-time: It will take about 5 to 10 minutes to complete.
content.description: Use this estimator to find out how much money you could get from the Canada Disability Benefit. This is not an application for benefits.

eligibility.intro: To receive the Canada Disability Benefit, you must meet specific eligibility criteria. <cdbRequirementsLink>Consult the benefit eligibility requirements</cdbRequirementsLink>.

estimator-steps.intro: If you meet the eligibility criteria, use the benefits estimator to find out how much you may receive. The estimator will ask you questions about your:

content.result-disclaimer: This tool provides an estimate only. It doesn't guarantee that you'll be eligible or that you'll receive the amount estimated.

results.description: This estimator provides estimated benefit amounts for payments made between July 2025 and June 2026. Future benefit amounts may be higher. The results are not financial advice and are subject to change. For a more accurate assessment of your estimated benefits amount, please contact us.

common-law.item1: have been living with you for at least 12 continuous months. This includes any period you were separated for less than 90 days because of a breakdown in your relationship
common-law.item2: are the parent of your child by birth or adoption
common-law.item3: have custody and control of your child (or had custody and control immediately before the child turned 19 years of age) and your child is wholly dependent on that person for support
common-law.text: Common-law: you are living in a conjugal relationship with someone to whom you are not married and to whom at least one of the following situations applies. They:

additional-info.divorced: Divorced: you were married and are now legally divorced
additional-info.married: Married: you are legally married to someone.

separated.p1: Separated: you have been living apart from your spouse or common-law partner because of a breakdown in the relationship for a period of at least 90 days and you have not reconciled.
separated.p2: Once you have been separated for 90 days, the effective day of your separation is the date you started living apart. You would still be considered to have a spouse or common-law partner if there is no breakdown in the relationship and you were living apart for reasons such as work, studies, or health problems.
separated.p3: Note: Generally, you are not considered separated if your spouse or common-law partner is incarcerated or does not live in Canada, as long as there is no breakdown in your relationship

additional-info.single: Single: you are single and another status does not apply
additional-info.widowed: Widowed: your spouse or common-law partner is deceased.

next-steps.apply-cdb: Apply for the Canada Disability Benefit
next-steps.learn-more: Learn more about the Canada Disability Benefit

married-common-law.cdb-partner-result: If both you and your partner are receiving the Canada Disability Benefit, you could receive a monthly amount of {{result}}.
married-common-law.intro: The monthly benefit amount you could receive depends on whether your partner is receiving the Canada Disability Benefit.
married-common-law.non-cdb-partner-result: If your partner is not receiving the Canada Disability Benefit, you could receive a monthly amount of {{result}}.

your-estimate.note: Please note that you may be able to receive retroactive payments for past months that you were elligible, but not for months before June 2025. Contact us to find out more.

single.intro: You could be eligible to receive:
single.result: A monthly amount of {{result}} from the Canada Disability Benefit.

results.disclaimer-alert: This estimate is based on the information you provided and assumes that you meet the eligibility criteria for the Canada Disability Benefit.
